raw_text:
France v Wales (Sat)
 
 Stade de France, Paris
 
 Saturday, 26 February
 
 1600 GMT
 
 BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website
 
 France may have beaten Scotland and England but they were tedious and uninspired throughout both matches. Wales, on the other hand, have played some fine rugby and have made their best start since they last won the title in 1994. They also have a good record at the Stade de France, having won their first two games there, in 1999 and 2001. Wales have made two changes from the team that thrashed Italy 38-8 in Rome.
 
 Kevin Morgan takes over from his injured Newport-Gwent Dragons colleague Hal Luscombe on the right wing. In the pack Neath-Swansea Ospreys forward Ryan Jones bas been brought on the blind-side flank to beef up the Wales back row in place of Jonathan Thomas. Wales coach Mike Ruddock is determined that his team will not go into their shells after their promising start to the championship. "Graham Henry (former Wales coach) said a couple of years ago that we should 'be bold' when going to France, and he was proved right," said Ruddock. "That is a great way to approach the game, and something we will further endorse with the players this week."
 
 Despite their stuttering displays in their first two games defending champions France are also unbeaten. Under-pressure coach Bernard Laporte has made four changes, with Yannick Nyanga, the debutant Julien Laharrague, Aurelien Rougerie and Yannick Jauzion coming into the side. France have been criticised for the absence of traditional "French flair" as they have ground their way to victory so far this year but captain Fabien Pelous sees hope on the horizon. "I get the impression we are getting better," he said. "Against Wales, which is different from the teams we have beaten, I hope we can show our proper game."
 
 J Laharrague; A Rougerie, Y Jauzion, D Traille, C Dominici; Y Delaigue, D Yachvili; S Marconnet, S Bruno, N Mas; F Pelous (capt), J Thion; S Betsen, Y Nyanga, J Bonnaire (Bourgoin).
 
 W Servat, O Milloud, G Lamboley, I Harinordoquy, P Mignoni, F Michalak, J-P Grandclaude.
 
 G Thomas (capt); K Morgan, T Shanklin, G Henson, S Williams; S Jones, D Peel; G Jenkins, M Davies, A Jones; B Cockbain, R Sidoli; R Jones, M Williams, M Owen.
 
 R McBryde, J Yapp, J Thomas, R Sowden-Taylor, G Cooper, C Sweeney, R Williams.
llama3.2:1b: France and Wales played at the Stade de France in Paris on Saturday, 26 February.
Wales won both of their matches against England and Scotland, with a promising start to their championship season.
The French team had two changes from last week's game, bringing back Ryan Jones from the Ospreys to replace Jonathan Thomas in the back row.
Despite France being unbeaten after two games, coach Bernard Laporte made four changes, introducing Yannick Nyanga, Julien Laharrague, Aurelien Rougerie, and Yannick Jauzion into his starting lineup.
France captain Fabien Pelous said he expects a better performance from Wales, citing the difference in their playing style against France.

The French team played with three forwards in Ryan Traille, Christophe Dominici, and Stephane Marconnet, while the Welsh team played with four forwards: Stefan Smith, Stephen Betsen, Yann Nyanga, and Julien Bonnaire.
llama3.2:3b:
France v Wales (Sat)

Stade de France, Paris

Saturday, 26 February
1600 GMT

BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website

Wales may have made a good start to the championship with their first win since 1994 against Italy, while France were uninspired.
The teams have different approaches: Wales coach Mike Ruddock wants his team to be bold, unlike previous games which were defensive-minded.
France's Bernard Laporte has made changes to try and revive the team's "French flair", having been criticized for lacking it this year.
gemma2:2b: France and Wales are set to play each other in a crucial Six Nations match at the Stade de France on Saturday.
Wales have had a strong start to the championship, while France has been criticized for its lack of flair despite their undefeated record.
Wales coach Mike Ruddock is urging his team to be bold against France, while France captain Fabien Pelous hopes they can finally show their true game in this match.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Wales team has improved significantly from their previous performance in France against the French national rugby team.
They have played a few new players and made changes to their side, but they are still struggling to perform well.
Their coach Mike Ruddock believes that his team can improve with proper training and techniques.
The Wales team will play another game on March 18th in Marseille.
qwen2.5:1.5b: France faces Wales in a Rugby World Cup match at the Stade de France on Saturday afternoon.
Despite initial disappointing performances from both teams, Wales' recent strong start and past success there provide motivation for their coach Mike Ruddock to avoid complacency.

While France's ground-level approach has been criticized, captain Fabien Pelous maintains hope that improved tactics could turn around their performance in this challenging contest against a determined Wales team.

France v Wales (Sat)  
Stade de France, Paris  
Saturday, 26 February  
1600 GMT BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website

Key points:  
- France lost their early starts but remain unbeaten; coached by Bernard Laporte with four changes.
- Wales have made a promising start to the championship, including thrashing Italy 38-8 in Rome.
- Changes for Wales include Kevin Morgan taking over Hal Luscombe at right wing and Ryan Jones joining the back row.
- France are determined not to play in their shells against Wales, as former coach Graham Henry had said before they won a game there.
- Captain Fabien Pelous sees hope of playing better rugby against Wales compared to previous matches.
- Teams will be: France with 14s named above; Wales with different substitutions.
opencoder:1.5b:
France v Wales (Saturday, 26 February, 16:00 GMT)

Stade de France, Paris

The BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website have provided key details such as the match outcome, weather conditions, and highlights of the match to date.
In terms of the performances, Wales have won their first two games there in 1999 and 2001.
They also have a good record at the Stade de France, having won their first two games in 19th century Paris.
During this period, they have made two changes from the team that thrashed Italy 38-8 in Rome.
In terms of the players, Wales coach Mike Ruddock is determined that his team will not go into their shells after their promising start to the championship.
Despite their stuttering displays, under-pressure coach Bernard Laporte has made four changes.
Yannick Nyanga, the debutant Julien Laharrague, Aurelien Rougerie and Yannick Jauzion come into the side for beef up the Wales back row in place of Jonathan Thomas.
France have been criticised for the absence of traditional "French flair" as they have ground their way to victory so far this year but captain Fabien Pelous sees hope on the horizon.
They have been criticized for their lack of a proper game, and their different style from those who have already won.
J Laharrague; A Rougerie, Y Jauzion, D Traille, C Dominici; Y Delaigue, D Yachvili; S Marconnet, S Bruno, N Mas; F Pelous (capt), J Thion; S Betsen, Y Nyanga, J Bonnaire (Bourgoin).
W Servat, O Milloud, G Lamboley, I Harinordoquy, P Mignoni, F Michalak, J-P Grandclaude.
G Thomas (capt); K Morgan, T Shanklin, G Henson, S Williams; S Jones, D Peel; G Jenkins, M Davies, A Jones; B Cockbain, R Sidoli; R Jones, M Williams, M Owen.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The French vs. Wales (Sat) match on February 26, 2023, at Stade de France in Paris.
- France defeated Scotland and England but showed unimpressive performances throughout both games.
- Wales, with a strong record at Stade de France (won two consecutive games), has made changes since their last success and has a good squad.
- Kevin Morgan replaces Hal Luscombe for Wales, with Ryan Jones taking forward.
Mike Ruddock emphasizes that "be bold" is the approach for Wales against France.
- Coach Bernard Laporte made four substitutions: Yannick Nyanga, Julien Laharrague, Aurelien Rougerie, and Yannick Jauzion.
- France remains unbeaten so far this season but lacks French flair.
- Fabien Pelous expresses hope for a successful game against Wales, noting the team's recent success.
tinyllama:1.1b: In a preview of France v Wales, the BBC, Radio 4, and this website will provide an insider's view on the match that could see France beat England or lose to Scotland, while Wales has made some bold changes in the team to start their championship campaign.
Despite being unbeaten and having scored six tries in the first two matches, France has shown a different style of rugby, and there is hope for improvement against Wales.
The team under-pressure coach Bernard Laporte has made four changes, with Yanick Nyanga, Auguste Rougerie, Yannick Jauzion, and Fabien Pelous coming into the side.
France's captain Fabien Pelous sees a chance to show their proper game after a good start to the championship year.
The match will be live on BBC1, Radio 4 LW, and this website at 1600 GMT on Saturday.
tinydolphin:1.1b: France's rugby team may not be the most talented in the world just yet, but they are proving to be more efficient with their play.
This weekend, France will face off against Wales at the Stade de France in a crucial match that could determine the outcome of the tournament.
In this match, both teams have shown flashes of brilliance and talent.
France, under coach Mike Ruddock, has had to adapt to their new lineup with key players like Kevin Morgan and Jonathan Thomas being injured.
Wales, on the other hand, has been playing some of their best rugby yet in their first two matches.
The key difference between the teams so far this year is that France has seemed more confident than Wales.
They have managed to find ways to win even when they're not at their best.
The match against Wales will be crucial for both teams as it sets the stage for them to determine who will become the champions of Europe in the coming weeks.
It all comes down to how well France can adapt and what new players they can add to their roster to create more opportunities for success on the field.

In conclusion, this match against Wales is not just an opportunity for France to prove themselves but also a chance for them to show that they have what it takes to be champions of Europe in the coming weeks.
phi:2.7b: France and Wales will compete in a rugby match at the Stade de France on Saturday 26 February.
Although France has been unbeaten this year, they have struggled to be entertaining during their previous games.
On the other hand, Wales has played well and won two matches at the stadium previously.
France made four changes for their game against Wales, while Wales also had a new player in Ryan Jones.
Both teams are eager to maintain momentum as they prepare for the match.
orca-mini:3b: On February 26th, France played Wales at the Stade de France and the French won 31-20 despite being uninspired throughout both matches.
Wales had a good record at the Stade de France but were made to look tedious and uninspired by the French.

However, Kevin Morgan was brought in on the right wing to beef up the Welsh back row to make up for Jonathan Thomas's absence, and Ryan Jones was brought in to fill the blind-side flank to beef up the Welsh back row.
French coach Bernard Laporte made four changes, with Yannick Nyanga, Julien Laharrague, Aurelien Rougerie, and Yannick Jauzion coming into the side.
French captain Fabien Pelous sees hope on the horizon.
Welsh coach Mike Ruddock is determined that his team will not go into their shells after their promising start to the championship.
Despite their stuttering displays in their first two games, defending champions France have remained unbeaten.
hermes3:3b:

Wales to play against France at Stade de France in Paris on Saturday (26th February).
Wales have a good record at the venue and are expected to challenge the defending champions.
France has made changes to their team due to under-pressure coach Bernard Laporte.
Wales' Kevin Morgan replaces Hal Luscombe, Ryan Jones is introduced into back row as well.

Despite France's strong record and unbeaten run, their first two matches have shown a lack of flair and inspiration.
Wales, on the other hand, have started well with fine rugby and are determined not to ease up after a promising championship start.
Key changes have been made for this match, including Kevin Morgan replacing Hal Luscombe on the right wing and Ryan Jones coming on at blind-side flanker for Jonathan Thomas.
France's coach Bernard Laporte has made four adjustments to his lineup in hopes of showing their true game against Wales.
Captain Fabien Pelous of France believes they are improving and can display their proper game against Wales.

Coach Mike Ruddock emphasizes bold play against France.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Wales, having shown promising rugby and a strong start since their last title win in 1994, will face defending champions France at Stade de France on Saturday, February 26, 2023 (16:00 GMT).
Wales has made two changes to their starting lineup, replacing injured players with Ryan Jones and Kevin Morgan.
Coach Mike Ruddock emphasizes boldness and not retreating after a good start.
Despite France's unbeaten record this year and four changes by coach Bernard Laporte, captain Fabien Pelous believes the team is improving.
The match pits Wales' skillful play against France's gritty approach, with both teams aiming to display their best rugby.
